html.p: Concepts and contexts are the basis of Conceptual Search but they don't, on their own, support a very nuanced view of the world. A true Cognitive Computing system, a system designed to "think" like we do, needs to understand nuance.

Scianta Extreme Search for Splunk employs the notion of "hedges" to capture nuanced variation to concepts. Hedges are linguistic modifiers, adjectives, that modify the meaning of a concept. Currently, Extreme Search for Splunk supports the following linguistic hedges:

Hedges allow us to look for people who are "very tall" or network segments where network latency is "extremely long" or performance that is "not typical". Just like in natural language a hedge acts as an adjective to alter the meaning of a term. Remember that our concepts are characterized mathematically by a membership function. Hedges act to change the shape of a term's membership function in a way that is appropriate to the linguistic meaning of the hedge.

Figure 1 illustrates a context pertaining to a common demonstration data set , the FAA flight statistics data set. The data set includes a record of flight characteristics for every domestic commerical airline flight in the United States,

The context depicted is that of ArrDelay, the Arrival Delay of commercial flights. In this context, we've defined five terms: incredible, early, ontime, late and outrageous. As we've said, the terms used were defined by the user. In this case, the term "incredible" is used to describe flights where the arrival time was significantly earlier than scheduled. "Outrageous" describes flights where the arrival delay was very long. The "Ontime" term is characterized by a bell-shaped curve centered around the scheduled arrival time.
Figure 1
The term Ontime is isolated in Figure 2. We'll use Ontime to illustrate the effect of various hedges on a target concept.
Figure 2
Figure 3

Figure 3 is a graph of the concept of Ontime, as modified by the hedge extremely. Note that the resulting hedged concept Extremely Ontime is more narrow, the resulting values closer to the scheduled arrival time at the center of the Ontime bell curve. This is linguistically consistent with what we mean when we say "Extremely Ontime".
Figure 4

Figure 4 is a graph of the concept of Ontime, as modified by the hedge somewhat. The resulting hedged concept Somewhat Ontime is wider, the resulting values deviating more from the scheduled arrival time at the center of the Ontime bell curve. This is also linguistically consistent with what we mean when we say "Somewhat Ontime".
Figure 5
Figure 5 is a graph of the concept of Ontime, as modified by the hedge not. The resulting hedged concept Not Ontime is what we'd expect: the mathematical inverse of the term Ontime.
Figure 6

If you were asked to draw the hedged concept Above Ontime, you'd probably draw something like Figure 6. This is the term Ontime, as modified by the hedge above. The hedge Below works in a similar fashion, encompasing values below the center of Ontime.

Here things start to get interesting. As humans, we're used to thinking about concepts modified by any number of adjectives. For example, you might decide that the latest reality TV show is "not very watchable". Both Not and Very are hedges to the term Watchable. Scianta Extreme Search supports an unlimited number of hedges applied to a concept.
Figure 7

The chart in Figure 7 depicts the compound hedge Not Very applied to the term Ontime. As we'd expect, the first hedge, Very, narrows the set. The second hedge, Not, inverts Very. Note that the hedge closest to the term is applied first.
Figure 8

Just as in human thought, the order in which we apply linguistic modifiers affects the result. Figure 8 shows the result of Very Not Ontime. In this case, the hedge Not is applied first. Then the hedge Very is applied, making the results "more not" than without the Very hedge. As we see in Figure 9, this notion of an unlimited number of compound hedges can be taken to the extreme.
Figure 9

Figure 9 is the result of the following querry in Extreme Search for Splunk: Quite Extremely Not Somewhat Close to Below Ontime. If it makes your head hurt trying to figure out what this means, you're not alone. The takeaway is this: If you can dream it up, Extreme Search will search for it, right there in the Splunk search bar.

Cognitive computing requires an understanding of human thought and the language used to describe that thought. Our baker's dozen linquistic hedges go a long way toward capturing the important linguistic modifiers used in human thought, as long as you speak English and know which words we've chosen to represent each hedge. That would not make for a particularly powerful Conceptual Search system. Human-Centered Computing should not require the user to understand which particular linguistic forms the system thinks are important. In order to better understand the linguistic forms the user has chosen, Extreme Search supports synonyms.

If your were paying particularly close attention during the discussion of highly complex hedges in Figure 9, you may have picked up on the use of Quite in the hedged term Quite Extremely Not Somewhat Close to Below Ontime. You may have noticed that "quite" is not included in the Extreme Search list of hedge words. The word quite is treated by Extreme Search as a synonym for the hedge somewhat. The word "quite" is listed in a synonyms file called synonyms.csv which resides in the xtreme/lookups/ directory. The synonyms.csv file is a simple two factor comma separated values table, with values stated as word,hedge. A reserved hedge word "_noise" allows the system to ignore noisewords such as "a", "an", "to" and "the".
If you look at synonyms.csv you'll see the following two lines:
These two lines allow quite to be treated as somewhat and the phrase close to to be treated as close.

The Extreme Search synonyms.csv file can be modified by the user. This allows Extreme Search for Splunk to be easily customized to support multiple languages as well as industry, company or use-case-specific hedges. Non-English synonyms files are availabe from Scianta Analytics.
